channel.title: math.GN updates on arXiv.org
channel.description: math.GN updates on the arXiv.org e-print archive.

item.title: Combinatorial $n$-od covers of graphs
item.description: arXiv:2506.11979v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We introduce the notion of a combinatorial $n$-od cover, for $n \geq 3$, which is a tool that may be used to show that certain continua embedded in the plane are not simple $n$-od-like. Using this tool, we generalize a classic example of Ingram, and give a construction, for each $n \geq 3$, of an indecomposable plane continuum which is simple $(n+1)$-od-like but not simple $n$-od-like, and such that each non-degenerate proper subcontinuum is an arc. These examples may be compared with related constructions of Kennaugh [10].
item.dc:creator: Logan C. Hoehn, Hugo Adrian Maldonado-Garcia

item.title: A note on intrinsic topologies of groups
item.description: arXiv:2506.11500v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: We investigate topologies on groups which arise naturally from their algebraic structure, including the Frech\'et-Markov, Hausdorff-Markov, and various kinds of Zariski topologies. Answering a question by Dikranjan and Toller, we show that there exists a countable abelian group in which no bounded version of the Zariski topology coincides with the full Zariski topology. Complementing a recent result by Goffe and Greenfeld, we show that on any group with no algebraicity the semigroup Zariski topology is hyperconnected and hence, in many cases, is distinct from the group Zariski topology. Finally, we show that on the symmetric groups, the semigroup Hausdorff-Markov topology coincides with the topology of pointwise convergence.
item.dc:creator: S. Bardyla, L. Elliott, J. D. Mitchell, Y. P\'eresse

item.title: A Minimal Non Hausdorff Counterexample in Covering Space Theory
item.description: arXiv:2506.00031v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: This note presents a concrete and deliberately simple example that pinpoints why the Hausdorff condition on the total space is indispensable in classical covering space theory. Starting from the well known line with k origins, a one dimensional manifold that is non Hausdorff at exactly k isolated points, we embed a single copy of the real line in a punctured disc and collapse it onto the puncture. The resulting map behaves exactly like a k sheeted covering away from the puncture, yet every standard covering-space principle collapses at that single fibre: unique path and homotopy lifting fail, monodromy cannot be defined, and all deck transformations reduce to the identity. Because the total space is nevertheless contractible and otherwise well behaved, the example is minimal in both dimension and complexity. We verify that the map fits into none of the usual generalisations (branched covers,etale spaces, Brazas semicoverings) and outline why any future theory of covers over non-Hausdorff spaces will require genuinely new structure, perhaps of a stack-theoretic nature. The aim is not to overturn classical results, but to provide a clean test case and an invitation: extending covering theory beyond the Hausdorff world demands tools that can record fibres whose points are distinct yet topologically indistinguishable.
item.dc:creator: Abhiram Sripat

item.title: Definable separability and second-countability in o-minimal structures
item.description: arXiv:2405.07114v2 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: We show that separability and second-countability are first-order properties among topological spaces definable in o-minimal expansions of $(\mathbb{R},<)$. We do so by introducing first-order characterizations -- definable separability and definable second-countability -- which make sense in a wider model-theoretic context. We prove that, within o-minimality, these notions have the desired properties, including their equivalence among definable metric spaces, and conjecture a definable version of Urysohn's Metrization Theorem.
item.dc:creator: Pablo And\'ujar Guerrero
